text: CLOSE ON JOKER (30's), tears in his eyes from laughing so hard. He's trying to get it under control. His greasy, bl hair is matted down. He's wearing an old, faded red hoode zip-up sweatshirt, a threadbare gray scarf, thin from yea of use, hangs loosely around his neck. WE NOTICE TWO FADED OLD SCARS cut at the corners of his mouth. Almost forming a smile. He's sitting across from an overworked SOCIAL WORKER (50' African American. Her office is cramped and run-down in a cramped and run-down building. Stacks of folders piled hi in front of her. She just sits behind her desk, waiting for his laughing f to end, she's been through this before. Finally it subsid Joker takes a deep breath, pauses to see if it's over. Beat.
--is it just me, or is it getting crazier out there? Despite the laughter, there's real pain in his eyes. Something broken in him. Looks like he hasn't slept in da
It's certainly tense. People are upset, they're struggling. Looking for work. The garbage strike seems like it's been going on forever. These are tough times. (then)
How 'bout you. How's the job? Still enjoying it?
Yeah, I   mean, it's different each day, so   I really like that. I don't think I   could ever work in an office.   Behind a desk.
(beat) No offense. She smiles. Writes something down. Looks at the clock, sh running late for her next appointment.
Have you been keeping up with your journal?
Everyday.
Great. Did you bring it with you? Beat.
(dodging the subject) I'm sorry. Did I bring what?
(impatient; she doesn't have time for this) Arthur, last time I asked you to bring your journal with you. For these appointments. Do you have it?
Yes ma'am. Beat.
Can I see it? He reluctantly reaches into his bag. Pulls out a weathere notebook. Slides it across to her--

I've been using it as a journal, but also a joke diary. Funny thoughts or, or observations-- Did I tell you I'm pursuing a career in stand-up comedy? She's half-listening as she flips through his journal.
No. You didn't.
I think I did.
She doesn't respond, keeps flipping through his journal--
Oh yeah. Because of what your mother said,-- about your purpose. "To bring laughter and joy to the world," right?

Right. ANGLE ON JOURNAL, pages and pages of notes, all in neat, angry-looking handwriting. Also, cut out photos from hard pornographic magazines and some crude handmade drawings. A flash of anger crosses Joker's face. We see him picking his right eyebrow, almost obsessively. Trying to stay cal His eyebrow is actually half-gone. Something he does a lo
I didn't realize you wanted to read it. The social worker gives him a look, then reads something the pages that gives her pause.

(reading out loud) "I just hope my death makes more sense than my life." She looks up at Joker. He just stares back. Lets it hang there for a beat. Then he laughs a little, even though he doesn't think it' funny--
Yeah. I mean, that's just--
Does my reading it upset you? He leans in.
No. I just,-- some of it's personal. You know?
I understand. I just want to make sure you're keeping up with it. She slides his journal back to him. He holds it in his la
What about your mom? How's she feeling?
She has good days. But mostly bad. It's been a big help having me there. She really needs me.
Seems like she's been sick a lot since you got home.

(nods) Yeah, it's good I'm there. When I was in the hospital, after my last episode-- she was having trouble getting over there to visit. She looks back up at the clock, she needs to get to her n appointment.
All right. So, I'll see you again, two weeks from today? He nods. But keeps sitting there for a moment. She stands up, trying to signal it's time for him to leav
Is there something else I can help you with, Arthur? My next appointment is waiting. He just keeps sitting there.
Yeah, I was wondering if you could ask the doctor to increase the dosage on my medications? Nothing seems to make a difference.
(looking over his record) Do you know which ones you'd like increased? Shakes his head, no.
Have you been sleeping?
(lying)
Some. She glances at his file again.
Arthur, you're on seven different medications. Surely they must be doing something. He finally stands up. Zips up his faded red sweatshirt. Looks at her--
I just don't wanna feel so bad anymore.

head_text.subj: TITLE

text: GOTHAM SQUARE IS CLOGGED WITH TRAFFIC. Non-stop honking horns, pedestrians crowding the sidewalk. Huge billboards giant movie marquees, garbage bags piled high everywhere. Underneath it all we hear a TINKLING PIANO playing someth bouncy and fast-paced. FROM ACROSS THE BUSY CITY STREET, we see Joker. He's dres as a sad-faced HOBO CLOWN. This is his job. Dressed in tattered clothes, dark five o'clock shadow pai on his face, big bulbous red nose, his mouth's outlined i white, turned down at the corners. He's holding up a sign in front of Kenny's Music Shop tha reads, "EVERYTHING MUST GO!" A banner above the store rea "GOING OUT OF BUSINESS!" Behind him, an OLD MAN plays a p on the street. Both of them there to draw attention to th big sale going on in the store. Joker's doing a little Charlie Chaplin like waddle to the music. Most people walk right past, ignoring him. A few b into him by mistake. JOKER SEES A GROUP OF FIVE BOYS, no more than 15-years-ol walking toward him. He moves out of their way. They crack laughing when they see him. Start making fun of him.
Joker ignores them, tries to do his job the best he can w maintaining some dignity. Keeps dancing and holding up th sign. One of the kids knocks the sign out of Joker's hands--
Suck my dick, clown. The kids laugh. Joker doesn't say anything. Just bends ov to pick up the sign-- Another kid kicks him in the ass--

Whoops. Joker falls face first onto the sidewalk. Oddly, the old playing the piano picks up the pace of the music-- The kids crack up. One of the boys grabs Joker's sign and takes off running across the street-- The other kids follow, weaving through traffic-- Joker gets up and gives chase. He needs his sign back. He almost gets hit by a taxi, spinning out of the way jus time-- Spinning right into another taxi that stops just s of hitting him. Joker keeps running through traffic. People stare. A clow barreling down the street has got to be a joke--

The five boys are booking it down the crowded street laug and whooping it up. At the last second they take a sharp right turn down a cross street-- Joker almost overshoots the corner, slip-sliding in his b red shoes-- He rights himself and heads down after them-- Sees them running up ahead-- WHAP! Out of nowhere Joker gets hit in the face! He falls to the ground. One of the kids was hiding between parked cars and hit Jo with the "EVERYTHING MUST GO!" sign, splintering it in tw

The other kids turn back and walk up to Joker down on the ground. Joker reaches out, still trying to save the sign-- THE KIDS START KICKING AND BEATING THE SHIT out of Joker. It's brutal and vicious. Nobody on the street stops to he CLOSE ON JOKER'S HOBO CLOWN FACE, down on the ground. Swe running down his face, smearing his make-up. He doesn't e look like he's in pain. He just takes the beating. That stupid frown painted on his face.

Joker, makes his way toward the back of the crowded bus, walking with a slight limp, but keeping his head held hig His make-up's washed off, costume and props all shoved in big shopping bag slung over his shoulder. Some white grea paint still smudged on the sides of his face. He finds an empty seat in the back of the bus. Sees a sad eyed FOUR-YEAR-OLD GIRL, face puffy from crying, sitting her knees looking back at him. Her mother's facing forwar but even from behind you can tell she's angry. Joker sees the sad-eyed girl staring straight back at him doesn't know where to look, feeling self-conscious and sm He gets back into "character" smiling like a clown and co his face with his hands-- Starts playing the peek-a-boo g with her. The girl stares back at him for a moment then giggles--
(turns back to Joker; already annoyed)
Can you please stop bothering my kid?
I wasn't bothering her, I was--
(interrupts)

Just stop. AND SUDDENLY JOKER STARTS TO LAUGH. LOUD. He covers his m trying to hide it-- Shakes his head, laughter pausing for moment, but then it comes on stronger. His eyes are sad. actually looks like the laughter causes him pain.
People on the bus are staring. The girl looks like she's going to cry again.
You think that's funny?

Joker shakes his head no, but he can't stop laughing. He reaches in his pocket and pulls out a small card. Hands i the woman. CLOSE ON THE CARD, it reads: "Forgive my laughter. I have condition (more on back)" She turns the card over and there is a bunch of informati in small writing-- "It's a medical condition causing sudden, frequent, uncon doesn't match how you feel. It can happen in people with neurological conditions." She doesn't read it (but if you freeze frame the movie yo could). She just shakes her head annoyed and throws the c on the ground. Joker laughs harder. Tears running down his face. Not wanting to attract any more attention to himself, he pulls up his red hood, and uses his threadbare scarf to c his mouth, trying to muffle the laughter. He looks out at the city passing him by.

The bus pulls away, sun almost gone. Joker heads slowly down the litter-covered streets. Garba is piled along the sidewalks, the air thick with smog cre a haze over everything. The streets are crowded with the poor, the elderly and disenfranchised. Women with children in busted strollers. Homeless people sleeping on subway grates. Stray dogs. Hi one of the few white faces. Joker makes his way into a run-down drug store, behind hi two drunks fight on the corner, beating the shit out of e other. Joker, and nobody else for that matter, pays them attention. No one here gives a shit.
A shabby lobby in a building that was once probably prett nice, but now it's a dump. Joker checks his mailbox. He's holding a small white (prescription) bag in his hand. The mailbox is empty.
Joker steps onto the wheezing elevator, harsh fluorescent lights, graffiti on the walls. As the door closes, he hea

Wait!! He puts his foot out with some panache to stop the closin door-- He's a romantic at heart. Ding. And SOPHIE DUMOND (late 20's), tired eyes, hands filled w grocery bags, steps onto the elevator with GIGI, her 5-ye old daughter.
Thank you. (realizing)

Of course it's you,-- everyone else in this building is just so fucking rude. Joker nods "thanks." Holds his breath, hoping he doesn't start to laugh. Floors dinging as the elevator rises. Joker sees GiGi licking the dirty smudged elevator handra behind her mom.
How's your mom doing? He takes a deep breath, he's uncomfortable talking to her holds up the white prescription bag.
It's day to day. I'm doing everything I can to get her back on her feet. (re: pharmacy bag)
Picked up her medicine. Gonna make her some dinner.
(smiles; being polite)
She's lucky she has you-- Joker smiles thanks, can't help but glance at GiGi lickin the rail. Sophie finally notices. She wants to grab her but can't w her hands full. Tries to kick her away--
Jesus. Don't do that, GiGi! How many times have I told you that? (to Joker)
This building is so awful, isn't it? Joker just nods... he doesn't know what to say, but clear wants to continue this conversation with Sophie. The doors open. They all step off.
Okay. Well, tell your mom I said hello. And Sophie and GiGi walk down the hall-- the opposite way Joker. He just stands there for a beat. Heart beating fas
(calls out after her)
Hey Sophie-- She turns around.
I'll tell my mom you said hello. She smiles as in "yeah, that's what I said."

Old apartment, worn carpet. Nothing's new inside but it's fairly neat and well-kept. Joker closes the door behind him, leans his back against and swoons. Hears a deep purring sound. He looks down and sees an OLD ORANGE CAT, rubbing up against his leg. Then--
(shattering the moment, calls out)
Happy?! Did you check the mail before you came up?
Yes, Ma. Nothing. No letter.
You sure you looked? Sometimes I don't know where your head is. Joker glances back down and sees the cat is gone.
Yes I'm sure. And my head's right here. I'm gonna make you some dinner, okay?

head_text.subj: JOKER TEARS OPEN THE PRESCRIPTION BAG... A FLURRY OF PILL
BOTTLES TUMBLE OUT ONTO THE COUNTER.
SEE HIS NAME, "ARTHUR FLECK" ON THE ORANGE PILL BOTTLES,
GLIMPSE THE GENERIC DRUG NAMES, TEMAZEPAM... PERPHENAZINE
AHENELZINE... AMITRIPTYLINE... BENZEDRINE... DIAZEPAM...
MEPROBAMATE...
TAKES OUT ONE PILL FROM EACH THE TEMAZEPAM AND MEPROBAMAT
BOTTLES.
TWO PILLS BEING CRUSHED UP TO POWDER.
SPRINKLES THE POWDER ON TOP OF A TV DINNER.
SWALLOWS A HANDFUL OF PILLS FROM THE OTHER BOTTLES.
LOOKS DOWN AND SMILES AT THE ORANGE CAT LOOKING UP AT HIM
FROM THE COUNTER.

text: Joker brings the food to his mother, PENNY (70's), lying her bed. The TV is on, playing the local news. Joker sets the food down in front of his mother. He cover the pain from his beating the best he can-- His mother doesn't seem to notice anyway.
He must not be getting my letters.
Joker sits down on a chair next to the bed. JOKER
He's a busy man. MOM
Too busy for me? I worked for that family for 12 years. He always had a smile for me. Least he could do is write back. JOKER
Ma, eat. You need to eat. MOM
You need to eat. Look how skinny you are. Before Joker can say anything, his mother points to the n on the TV-- MOM
All day long it's more bad news. That's all there is. JOKER
Maybe you shouldn't watch so much television. MOM
(ignoring) He's the only hope for Gotham. He'll make a great mayor. Everybody says so. JOKER
(playful) Everybody who? Who do you talk to? MOM
Well everybody on the news. JOKER
Stop it. He's not even gonna run. Why would Thomas Wayne want to be mayor? He can do more good as a businessman. MOM
Because he cares about this city. And everyone in it-- that's why I can't believe he hasn't written me back.
JOKER
He will. Now eat some dinner. He feeds her a bite of the food. JOKER
How you feeling today? MOM
I don't know. It always hits me worse at night, you notice that? He shakes his head. JOKER
(teasing) Maybe it's the moon. Maybe you're a werewolf? HE HOWLS SOFTLY like a wolf. She laughs. MOM
It's not funny. Joker watches her as he cuts up some more of her food. MOM
Anyway, I wrote a new letter today. A better one. I want you to hand deliver it to him.
What? Why? MOM
Cause maybe the mailman is throwing them away. We should have tipped him at Christmas time. JOKER
Who tips their mailman? MOM
Some people do. Rich people do. Joker sighs, resigned. JOKER
Okay. I can try his office. Tomorrow.
Thank you. (she pats the bed)

Come sit. It's almost on. Joker gets into bed with her. CLOSE ON TELEVISION, intro to "LIVE WITH MURRAY FRANKLIN! and we HEAR THE ANNOUNCER over clips of comedy bits, star and Murray Franklin himself--

It's Live with Murray Franklin! Tonight Murray welcomes, Sandra Winger, comedian Skip Byron and the piano stylings of Yeldon & Chantel! As always, Don Ellis and his Jazz Orchestra. And now, without any further ado-- Murray Franklin! Joker and his mom watch from bed, this is a ritual of the

Late night. Joker's mom is dead asleep. Joker is alone in living room, which doubles as his bedroom. He can't ever sleep. He opens his worn notebook. Flips to a page titled "Jokes" and starts writing-- CLOSE ON WORDS, as he slowly writes: "The worst part abou having a mental illness is..." ANGLE ON JOKER, pausing, thinking it over for a moment. T he laughs to himself when he comes up with something. CLOSE ON WORDS, coming faster now, "...that people still expect you to behave as if you don't."

Joker's looking up at the intimidating steel and glass to he looks so small, holding his mom's letter in his hand. Bustle of professionals coming in and out of the company' corporate headquarters, Joker looks out of place. He heads inside through the giant glass doors.
Joker steps off an elevator and walks up to the white mar reception desk as if he belongs there--
Hello. I have a personal letter for Mr. Thomas Wayne.
Okay. You can leave it with me.
It's kind of important. I need to make sure he gets it himself.
Oh, in that case, I'll buzz you right in. Joker goes to enter--
I'm kidding. Leave it here. He laughs along with her, even though she's not laughing.
Oh. Right-- well, my mom used to work for the Wayne family-- for 12 years. She was their housekeeper. A couple other business people are now waiting behind Jok there for meetings.
That's great. But you can leave it with me or you can leave with the letter. Those are your options. Now please step aside.
Mr. Wayne knows her. Can you maybe at least call back to him? Tell him that I'm here.
Thomas Wayne is away on business. Joker is getting frustrated.
Okay. Well, can I have your name? So I know who I left it with.

Now Joker sees a GROUP OF MEN walking behind the glass th separates the reception area from the back offices. Among the group, he catches a glimpse of THOMAS WAYNE (60's), d tan, hair dyed so black it's almost blue.
Wait. He's right there. (goes up to the glass, shouts)
Mr. Wayne! Mr. Wayne. He starts banging on the glass... but the group keeps mov Not noticing him.
Sir. Please stop. Sir!! Joker keeps banging on the glass.

The glass doors swing open and Joker is forcibly thrown o the street. TWO LARGE SECURITY GUARDS stand over him. He is still holding the letter. He makes as if he's going to leave peacefully, then at th last minute, TAKES ANOTHER RUN AT THE DOOR-- The two guards stiff arm him.

The cramped locker room of a small talent booking agency. This is where Joker works. They "rent out" talent for par and events. Clowns, magicians, male strippers. Joker takes off his shirt, grimaces in pain as he moves. body's bruised from the beating he took chasing after his sign.
You okay? He turns. RANDALL (mid 50's), a big bear of a know-it-all standing there. He's a party clown as well. He's half-dre in his clown suit.
RANDALL
I heard about the beat down you took. Fucking savages. JOKER
It was just a bunch of kids. I should have left it alone. Randall opens his locker-- RANDALL
It's crazy out there. And it's only getting worse. JOKER
(nods) My mother says that the people nowadays lack empathy. RANDALL
What's empathy? JOKER
It means like "feeling for other people." RANDALL
Like sympathy? JOKER
Kind of. But different. Randall comes over, hands Joker a brown paper bag-- Joker looks inside. It's a GUN, a .38 snub-nose revolver. Joker looks up at him, confused-- RANDALL
Take it. I got a few. You gotta protect yourself out there, buddy. Too many wackos. As Joker stares at it-- RANDALL
(lowers his voice) It's a .38 snub-nose. Gets the job done if you ever need to use it. Usually pulling it out is enough. JOKER
I, I don't have the money for this,                   Randall.
Don't sweat it. You can pay me some other time. You're my boy. That lands with Joker, he smiles to himself.
(as he walks away)

But you didn't get it from me, okay? Joker nods. Puts the brown paper bag in his locker. Slowl starts to get dressed-- his eyes darting toward the bag a does. Another clown, GARY (30's), a dwarf, pops his head into t locker room.
Arthur,-- Hoyt wants to see you in his office.
What for?
No clue.

Joker still half-dressed, walks into the cramped office. His boss, HOYT VAUGHN (60's) sits behind a metal desk. Th office is a complete mess, newspapers and files litter th desk. A giant ashtray filled with cigarette butts. A cale of booking hangs on the wall. A scribbled, jumbled mess.
Hey Hoyt. Gary said you wanted to see me?
(without even looking up)
How's the comedy career? Are you a famous stand-up yet?
Not quite. Haven't even performed yet. Just been working my material. This business is all about fine- tuning. Now Hoyt looks up. Takes a drag from his cigarette.
Right. Joker goes to sit down-- HOYT
Don't sit. This will be quick. Joker stops in his tracks. HOYT

Look, I like you, Arthur. A lot of the guys here, they think you're a freak. But I like you. I don't even know why I like you. I mean, you don't say much. (beat) It's probably that stupid laugh. It gets me every time. Kills me. Unsure how to respond, Joker just nods. HOYT
But I got another complaint. And it's starting to piss me off. Joker takes a deep breath, maybe picks at his eyebrow. HOYT
Kenny's Music. Sunday. The guy said you disappeared. Never even returned his sign. JOKER
No. I got jumped. I told you about that. HOYT
For a sign? Bullshit. It makes no sense, just give him his sign back. He's going out of business for god's-- BANG! Out of nowhere, Joker slams his head into the wall. Head-butting it hard.
(taken aback) Hey! BANG! BANG! He does it two more times. Breaking the plast on the wall--
What the fuck, Arthur?!
(voice tightens)
I don't have his sign.                                    And Joker just stares at Hoyt, some blood forming on his forehead--

WE'RE AT THE FAR END OF AN ALLEY, about halfway down, cat glimpse of Joker still half-dressed on the other side of dumpster. From this vantage, all we can see is him furiou KICKING and STOMPING on something... or somebody. We don't hear anything. And we can't make out what it is he's so violently beating down. It could be a cat... a cardboard box... a homeless person We don't know. Joker just continues unleashing his rage--
Joker at the end of his work day, sitting in his spot tow the back of the bus. Across the aisle from him, he's innocently watching a you couple, playfully teasing each other.
Joker heading back home down the litter-covered streets l he does every night. Garbage still piled along the sidewa air still thick with smog. He's carrying the paper bag that Randall gave him.
Joker checks his mailbox. Empty.

Joker is on the elevator, as the door closes, he sticks h foot out to stop it. The door limps back open. Ding. He looks to see if anybody, if Sophie, is coming. He wait Hoping. The door starts to close on him again-- Right before it d he stops it with his foot again. Ding.
JOKER'S GIVING HIS MOM A BATH, being careful with her as shampoos her hair.
--so what did he say when you gave him the letter?
They wouldn't let me see him. (lying)
But they promised me it would get to him.
It's good they promised. He only works with the best. We should hear something soon. He fills an empty plastic container with some bath water.
Look up. She tilts her head back and he rinses her hair with the w from the container...
Why are these letters so important to you, Ma? What do you think he's gonna do?
He's gonna help us.
Help us how?
Get us out of here, take me away from this place and these-- these awful people.
You worked for him over 30 years ago. What makes you think he would help you? She looks at him with conviction.

Because Thomas Wayne is a good man. If he knew how I was living, if he saw this place, it would make him sick. I can't explain it to you any better than that. Joker nods. Annoyed, but not worth the argument. He stand to get her a towel.

I don't want you worrying about money. Everyone's been telling me they think my stand-up is ready for the big clubs. It's just a matter of time before I get a break. She steps into the towel. He's helping dry her off.
Happy, what makes you think you could do that?
What do you mean?
I mean, don't you have to be funny to be a comedian? Beat.
Joker's mom is out cold in her bedroom, a half-eaten plat food is next to her on the bed.

Joker sits on the couch. The TV is on, but the sound is o He holds the .38 SNUB-NOSE REVOLVER Randall gave him in h hand. He's never held a gun before, looks uncomfortable w it, the weight of it in his hand... He points it at the TV, hand trembling a bit... Points it the cat... Points it at his head. Looks closely at the grip. The barrel. The cylinder. Now casually pulls the trigger--

head_text.subj: BLAMMMMMMM

text: He jumps up off the couch. What the fuck!? He looks aroun a panic. His hands shaking. He shot a hole in the wall.
(awoken by the shot)
HAPPY!? What was that?
What?! He quickly turns up the TV volume. REALLY LOUD. Shoves th still smoking gun under the couch cushions.

head_text.subj: THAT NOISE
NOISE

text: He's inspecting the hole in the wall. Shouts back over th noise--

head_text.subj: I'M WATCHING AN OLD WAR MOVIE.
TURN IT DOWN

text: He heads for his mother's bedroom.
Joker looks in on his mom in her dark bedroom, can make o the outline of her body sitting up.
It's so loud.
I know. The Americans are really giving it to the Japs. He walks over to her in the darkness. Kisses her on the forehead.
(softly)
I'm sorry. I'll turn it down.
Joker is writing in his journal. He speaks softly to hims as he writes...
Why didn't Randall tell me the gun was loaded? He's my friend. With my luck, I could have killed someone. (beat)
I could have killed myself. CLOSE ON THE LAST LINE, he crosses out "could"... Writes... "should".
(still to himself)
I should have killed myself. CLOSE ON JOKER as he crosses out something again...
(louder to himself)
I should kill myself. Beat.

HANDHELD POV, see the run-down building where Joker lives from across the street. REVEAL, Joker is watching his own building on the far sid a parked truck. Red hood pulled up, covering his head. He waits. Watches. Now we see Sophie exiting the building with her daughter GiGi. Sophie's dressed more conservatively than when we previously met her.
Joker starts following them.
Sophie drops GiGi off at school. Joker's still watching. Following.
Sophie waits on the platform. Lights a cigarette. We see Joker, hidden behind a steel support beam-- watchi her from a distance.
Joker stands at the window between two subway cars. Just watching Sophie as she reads a book in the next car. The train comes to a stop and she exits. Joker exits as w
Nicer part of Gotham. Joker follows Sophie from a distanc watches as she walks into Gotham First National Bank. Sees her say hello to the guard. This is where she works. Joker just watches and waits.

A large, mid-level bank. Sophie is one of THREE BANK TELL working behind the plexiglass windows. Joker pulls the hood back off his head, takes a deep brea before he walks up to her window. She is looking down, counting her drawer. Takes another deep breath. Then--
Hello. I'd like to open an account. She looks up.
(surprised)
Hey, what are you doing up here?
JOKER
Oh, hi. That's weird. (pausing to see if he's gonna laugh; he's good) I didn't know you worked at a bank. SOPHIE
Pretty glamorous, right? Not getting the sarcasm, Joker nods. Looks around. JOKER
Very glamorous. Look at this place. She laughs. He stands there awkwardly for a moment looking around to what she's laughing about. Realizes she thought he was making a joke. Beat. JOKER
I'm a comedian. I do stand-up comedy. SOPHIE
Really? I had no idea. JOKER
Yeah. You know, I'm always making funny observations. Always on the look out for my next bit-- so it makes sense. SOPHIE
Right. Anyway, is there something I could help you with? Beat. JOKER
I said hi to my mom.
Excuse me? JOKER
Last week. You said to say hi to my mom. I did. Made her day. They are interrupted by the BRANCH MANAGER (50's), white, heavy-set, who has come up behind Sophie--
Everything okay here? He puts his heavy hand on Sophie's shoulder. She practica shudders from his touch.
Everything is fine Mr. Slotnick. Now he leans down and whispers something in her ear-- Jok just watches through the glass.
(shakes her head; to her manager)
No. He's not. He's interested in opening an account.
(to Joker)
Great. You just need to fill out a form. They are back there-- against the wall. As the manager talks, Sophie makes wide eyes at Joker, li "I almost got in trouble."
(covering; trying to act cool)
Okay. Thank you, sir. And thank you as well, Miss. Joker walks back to the wall by the forms. He fumbles around for a minute, clearly not there to open account. He begins filling out a form. Then--
(shouts out, to no one in particular)

head_text.subj: YOU KNOW WHAT
I'LL BE BACK. THANK YOU.

text: He walks out of the bank. Head in the clouds.
Joker sitting in the middle of a dark, crowded comedy clu People on dates. Groups of friends. All here to watch the stand-up. He sits at a small table by himself, watching t act on stage.
The comic on stage is killing it. The whole room is laugh and applauding. Everyone except Joker. He's watching. Studying. Diligently jotting down notes in notebook.

People are piling out of the club, onto the narrow street jumble of lit-up signs, most glowing yellow or red. Joker walks out alone, carrying his notebook. He sees a FLYER t to the entrance of the club. CLOSE ON THE FLYER, "Open mic night. Thursdays. 10pm." He rips the flyer off the wall.

Joker is working on his "Mr. Jingles" clown look, using t small mirror in his locker. Behind him a couple of other clowns are eating their lunch at a small table, not payin Joker any attention. Joker pauses half-finished, and stares at himself for a b He starts to examine the two small scars on the corners o his mouth, we really notice how they form a smile. I can't help you. If you want these records you have to get your mom to sign a patient disclosure form. I can have someone mail you one. Joker just sits there, thinking it all over for a moment. Then snatches the file off the clerk's desk-- The clerk grabs it as well. They play tug-of-war with the file, it's awkward and goes way too long. Finally, Joker shoves the guy hard and pull the file away--
He takes off running out of the office with it. The clerk watches for a beat, but does nothing.
Joker running down the hallway, files in his hands. Frant Unaware he is not being chased. Turns a corner and runs down another long hallway. Gets to a stairwell door and runs in.

Bounding down the steps. He stops at a landing below. Loo up, sees no one is chasing after him-- ANGLE ON JOKER, catching his breath. He opens the file, flipping through the records, finds the page the clerk wa reading. As he reads it over for himself, he HEARS his mo being interviewed for her psychiatric assessment, over 30 years ago.
He's not adopted-- he's Thomas                            Wayne's son. I work for him, I told                       you, I clean his house. He's always                       smiling at me.

location: EMERGENCY INTERVIEW ROOM, ARKHAM STATE HOSPITAL

text: (FLASHBACK)

Penny Fleck (late 20's) is sitting across the table from BENJAMIN STONER (50's), in a dreary small interview room, windows covered with security screens. Penny takes a drag a cigarette, her face is beaten to shit, nose battered, l busted up. Dr. Stoner is going over Penny's thick file, the same fil Joker's holding in his hands.

We went over this, Penny. You                             adopted him. We have all the                              paperwork right here.                                     Penny doesn't say anything, just smiles like she's in on big secret. And exhales smoke.
Dr. Stoner keeps going through the file, pulls out black white forensic photographs of three-year-old Joker's body DR. STONER

You also stood by as one of your                         boyfriends repeatedly abused your                        adopted son. And battered you.                           Penny looks at Dr. Stoner like he's crazy. MOM

He didn't do anything to me. Or to                       my boy. Can I go now, I don't like                       hospitals.                                               Dr. Stoner lays out the photographs in front of Penny-- Penny keeps smoking her cigarette, glances down at the photos, we catch glimpses of various bruises on parts of Joker's body... A filthy crib... A rope tied to the radiator...
Joker looking over the same black & white photographs HEARS his mother-- MOM (V0)
I never heard him crying. Not once.                      He's always been such a happy                            little boy.                                              DR. STONER (VO)

Penny, your son was found tied to a                      radiator in your filthy apartment,                       malnourished, with multiple bruises                      across his body and severe trauma                        to his head.                                             Joker looks up from the file when he hears/reads this, tu and looks at Penny's reaction-- HE'S NOW IN THE INTERVIEW ROOM WITH THEM, living what he's reading on the page. He sees his mother lean forward in her chair, glaring at Stoner-- MOM

That's not true. My apartment                            wasn't filthy. I keep a clean                            house.                                                   Joker just stares at his mother. Dr. Stoner looks at Penny, not sure how to respond to tha
(beat)
And what do you have to say about                        your son?                                                ANGLE ON PENNY, thinking it over, taking a drag off her cigarette.

I'm just glad I got to know him.                         Joker just keeps staring at her as she exhales-- JOKER BACK IN THE STAIRWELL LOOKS UP FROM THE FILE, looks like maybe there's cigarette smoke drifting in front of h face--
Joker walking fast toward the playground. Sees Sophie tal with some other moms, as GiGi and a few kids play on the monkey bars. Sophie walks toward him, still disturbed about last night
What the hell was that? You can't just walk into my apartment like that. He is taken aback by her anger--
No, wait,-- Sophie, we can get through this, that's why I'm here.
What are you talking about? What do you think this is?
I don't know. I mean I've never been with a woman "like that," but, this feels like a beginning to me.
Arthur, I was just being nice to you. I felt sorry for you. I have a boyfriend.
JOKER
You what? What? What kind of woman are you? Who does that? Some of the other mothers turn toward them-- SOPHIE
You need to leave. I'm not having this conversation with you. JOKER
(shouts) Why not? GiGi runs up to Sophie's side to see what's going on, to if her mother's okay. SOPHIE
(turns to her daughter) Go back with your friends, honey. Mommy's having a grown up talk. Before GiGi leaves Joker looks down at her-- JOKER

No. Don't listen to her GiGi, you need to hear this. Your mother's a bad person. She's a whore, she's seeing two men at once. You can't trust her,-- She'll break your fucking heart. Joker turns to go, behind him GiGi starts to cry. He's cl to tears himself. Sophie takes off after him, and reaches out and grabs him Joker spins quickly around to face her, looks like he mig even hit her-- JOKER
How come nothing ever comes easy for me? And Sophie slaps him hard across the face-- Then turns an walks away. CLOSE ON JOKER, he begins to laugh--

Joker manically pacing around the living room, banging th side of his head with his hand, muttering to himself, alm like he's having a conversation with himself, taking part some story in his head, in the background the 11:00 News playing on the television. Footage of a protest in front of Wayne Tower... Protester "Joker" clown masks... Hear the NEWS ANCHOR's bombastic v over, "The anger and resentment that's been building up f weeks now, seems close to exploding. Protestors today, ma dressed as clowns, took to the streets in front of Wayne Tower in one of many planned demonstrations." Joker stops when he hears this, turns to the flickering screen-- ANGLE ON TELEVISION, protesters in the middle of a massiv crowd outside a Wayne Tower.
You'll see what's gonna happen at City Hall next Thursday. We're gonna-- Joker sits down on the couch eyes, leaning forward to mak sure he's seeing what he's seeing--
(interrupts; screaming into camera)

[Beep] the rich, [beep] the media, [beep] the blacks, [beep] the whites, [beep] everybody. They all [beeped] us, that's what this is [beeping] about! CLOSE ON JOKER, doesn't even blink, it's like he's watchi himself on television.

Sun peeking through the windows. PHONE RINGING. Joker ope his eyes. His orange cat is sitting on his chest, staring at him. Joker finally got some sleep. He lies there for a beat. P still ringing, until the machine picks up the call.
SHOW BOOKER (ON MACHINE)

This message is for Arthur Fleck. My name is Shirley Woods, I work on the Murray Franklin show.                               Joker sits up, the cat jumps off his chest. He can't beli what he's hearing. He gets up off the couch as the woman continues to leave a message on the machine-- SHOW BOOKER (ON MACHINE)

I don't know if you're aware, but                       Murray played a clip of your stand-                     up on the show recently and we've                       gotten an amazing--                                     Joker picks up the phone-- JOKER
(into phone; skeptical)                             Who is this?                                            SHOW BOOKER (OVER PHONE)
Hi, this is Shirley Woods from                          Murray Franklin Live. Is this                           Arthur?                                                 Beat.
(into phone)                                     Yes.                                                    Joker looks down at the cat purring at his feet, and kick away. SHOW BOOKER (OVER PHONE)

Hi Arthur. Well, as I was saying--                      we've gotten a lot of calls about                       your clip, amazing responses. And,                      Murray asked if I would reach out                       to see if you would come on as his                      guest. Can we set up a day?                             PUSH IN ON JOKER'S FACE, as it sinks in. JOKER
(into phone)                                        Murray wants me to come on the                          show?                                                   SHOW BOOKER (OVER PHONE)
Yes. Isn't that great? He'd love to                     talk to you, maybe do some of your                      act. Does that sound good to you?
As the PUSH IN ON JOKER finishes. Hold.

JOKER WALKS INTO HIS MOTHER'S SHARED HOSPITAL ROOM, passi an elderly wheezing woman in the bed closest to the door. Sees his mom in her bed by the window. He pulls the blue curtain separating the beds, giving him his mother some privacy. Sits down on the edge of her bed She smiles when she sees him. Still fairly incapacitated. He leans down close to her. Speaks softly, but filled wit rage--
Ma, remember how you used to tell me that God gave me this laugh for a reason. That I had a purpose. To bring laughter and joy into this fucked up world,-- She looks at him confused.

HA! It wasn't God, it was you or,                         or one of your boyfriends,-- how                          could you let that happen? What kind of woman are you? What kind of mother are you? She looks away.
What's my real name? Her whole body is shaking, overwhelmed with emotion.
C'mon, Ma, I know I was adopted. What's my name? Who am I really? She looks back him, struggles to speak--
H-h-happ--
(interrupting, snaps at her)
Happy?! I'm not happy. I haven't been happy for one minute of my entire fucking life. He reaches behind her, grabs one of her pillows--
But you know what's funny? You know what really makes me laugh? Leans down closer, face-to-face with her--
I used to think my life was nothing but a tragedy, but now, now I realize it's all just a fucking                           comedy.

Other side of the blue divider curtain. We see Joker's fe shifting a little. SLOWLY WE PULL OUT, backing out of the room. Leaving behi whatever Joker's doing to his mother on the other side of curtain. And we HEAR applause...

JOKER'S STUDYING VHS TAPES OF "MURRAY FRANKLIN LIVE!", st audience applauding Murray... He jots down notes in his w notebook... Watches the guests come out... how they cross stage... how they greet Murray... how they sit down... if they cross their legs or not... studying how he should ac how to be a person like other people. His cat sits on top of the TV watching him the whole time never taking her eyes off him.

Practicing. Joker walks across the living room like he's the show, smiling, waving to the "audience"... He mimes shaking Murray's hand... Mimes unbuttoning his jacket and sits down. He smiles and pulls out his worn notebook from pocket--
You wanna hear a joke, Murray?                            He "waits" for Murray to answer. Then Joker nods okay and opens his notebook--
(reading)

Knock-knock.                                              His cat still watching him, now at his feet. Joker crosse and uncrosses his legs... Looks uncomfortable. He glances down at his cat. It's as if he can hear the ca talking to him.
(nods; frustrated)

Yeah, I don't know if I should cross or uncross 'em. Both feel completely unnatural. Joker gets up off the couch and walks back across the liv room. Waves to the "audience"... Mimes shaking Murray's hand... Mimes unbuttoning his coat and sits down... Cross his legs.

Thanks for having me on, Murray. I                        can't tell you how much this means                        to me, it's been a life long dream.                       I have a joke for you--                                   Joker stands back up. Looks down at the cat again.
You're right. You're right, uncrossed is better. Joker sits back down... Doesn't cross his legs this time.

WIDE SHOT, a lone figure in a vast sea of mass graves, gr headstones. This is where they bury the poor and the unclaimed dead. Joker stands by his mother's grave. His head bowed, face his hands, his body convulsing. He's dressed in an ill- fitting faded rust colored suit, almost shiny from all th wear. Behind him in the distance, the TWO DETECTIVES stan their parked car on the cemetery roadway. Sun dying in th sky.
CLOSE ON JOKER'S FACE BURIED IN HIS HANDS, see he's laugh impossible to tell if he's laughing because of his condit or laughing for real.
Joker walking away from his mother's grave, goes to the t detectives -- GARRITY and BURKE -- waiting for him by the unmarked car. His face is still red, tears in his eyes fr laughing.
(wiping his eyes; restrained anger)
You shouldn't be here. It's not right.
We just came to pay our respects. Sorry about your mother.
Yeah, it's too bad. Joker just stares at the two detectives. Awkward beat.
Where is everybody?
It's always been just me and her. Joker pauses for a moment, then starts to walk away.
(calls out)
We saw you on Murray Franklin. Joker turns back to them.
You saw that?
Yeah. Heard you were on, so we got a videotape.
I just couldn't tell if you were actually trying to be funny or not.
Yeah, well I guess you didn't get the joke.
Listen, we need to clear a few things up, we spoke to the hospital administrator--
(interrupting)
Which hospital?
The Children's Hospital. (reminding)
The night you were fired. He said it didn't look like a prop gun, it was heavy, like a real one. We have some more questions for you.
I just buried my mother. The detectives share a look. Garrity pulls out a card. Ha it to Joker.
We can do it tomorrow. But you need to come down to the precinct-- first thing in the morning.
(looks down, reading the card)
Right. Thanks for coming.
Of course. Joker looks back up.
That was a joke. We hear applause followed by the familiar opening riff to ELTON JOHN'S "Bennie & the Jets".
JOKER'S LEANING OVER THE BATHROOM SINK, water running. He wearing rust colored pants and a white "beater" T-shirt.

A "Joker" clown mask hangs off the dirty mirror by its elastic band. "Bennie & the Jets" blaring from a tran radio turned all the way up. Joker lifts his head up. He's dyed his hair green like hi old "Mr. Jingles" clown wig-- but he's missed spots. Some his hair is still its original color, sticking out all he skelter.

Now he's smearing white grease-paint all over his face. He's dancing along to the music, gyrating and thrusting h hips to the beat, as he glances at the mask hanging from mirror, trying to copy how it looks... A copy of a copy o himself. He barely hears someone banging on the front door over th loud music-- Doesn't answer. Joker just keeps putting on his make-up, dancing provocatively to the music. More banging on the front door. Joker casually opens the medicine cabinet. Finds some old rusty scissors and turns the radio off--

Joker unlocks the locks, keeping the security chain latch and cracks open the door,-- Sees Randall. Looks down, and sees Gary next to him. Undoes the chain and opens the doo for them-- Randall and Gary get a look at Joker's face, his dyed gre hair still wet, streaking white grease-paint smeared over part of his face--
(re: his look)
Hey Arthur, how's it going? You get a new gig? Joker shakes his head no, steps aside so they can come in palming the scissors in his hand--
You must be goin' down to that rally at City Hall. Right? I hear it's gonna be nuts.
JOKER
Is that today? Randall looks at him and laughs-- RANDALL
Yeah. What's with the clown-face then? Joker shuts the door behind them. Locks the chain-lock. JOKER
My mom died. RANDALL

(nodding)                                           Yeah we heard. That's why we're                         here. Figured you might wanna go                        out, get a drink or something?                          Joker doesn't answer. Awkward beat. GARY
We don't wanna bother you. Randall                      just thought we should come and pay                     our respects.                                           RANDALL
Yeah, we're family. We gotta stick                      together.                                               Joker stares at Randall. JOKER
(beat)                                              It's not a good time. I'm in the                        middle of something here.                               GARY

Of course. No problem. Another                          time.                                                   Gary turns to go. Randall pauses for a moment, has someth else to say before he leaves-- RANDALL
Yeah. Another time, then. Oh hey,--                     one other thing--                                       He takes a step closer to Joker--
RANDALL

Listen, the cops have been poking                       around the shop, they're talking to                     all the clowns about those subway                       murders and--                                           GARY
(interrupting)                                      They didn't talk to me.                                 RANDALL

(snaps at Gary)                                     That's because the suspect was a                        regular-sized person. If it was a                       fucking midget you'd be in jail                         right now.                                              (turns back to Joker)                               Anyway, Hoyt said they were looking                     for me, and, and I just wanna see                       what you said. You know, make sure                      our stories line up, bein' that                         you're my boy and--                                     AND JOKER STABS THE SCISSORS AS DEEP AS HE CAN into Randa neck. Blood spurts. Randall screams. Gary stumbles back i shock-- GARY
(screaming) What the fuck what the fuck WHAT

head_text.subj: THE FUCK--

text: Joker pulls them out and jams them into Randall's eye bef he can react. The sound is sickening. Gary's screaming in background-- Randall blindly fights back, screaming in pain, flailing arms, his own blood blinding him-- Joker grabs Randall by the head -- all of his pent up rag and frustration pouring out of him -- AND SLAMS HIS HEAD AGAINST THE WALL. AGAIN. And AGAIN. And AGAIN. Joker lets go of Randall's head, and Randall drops to the ground. Joker leans back against the wall, out of breath, kind of slides down the wall to the floor-- Sees Gary huddled in the corner, trembling with fear--
(catching his breath)
I'm gonna be on TV tonight. Can you believe it? Gary doesn't answer. Doesn't move--
It's okay, Gary. You can go. Gary backs away toward the door. Joker sits there for a moment, breathing heavy, wipes Randall's blood off his fa

Hey, Art? Joker turns, sees Gary at the front door. He points up hi to the chain-lock. He can't reach it. Joker just shakes his head to himself and gets up to unlo the door. He walks past Gary who's still trembling almost too afrai look up at him. Joker leans over him and undoes the chain opens the door. Gary bolts, running down the hallway as f as he can--

(Over the following, we don't see Joker's face. We don't reveal his finished "look" just yet.) CLOSE PICKING UP HIS NOTEBOOK, fanning through the pages- Pausing at the BLACK & WHITE RIPPED PHOTO OF BRUCE WA a moment. Continues, stopping at the same entry from the opening scene-- CLOSE ON WORDS, "I just hope my death make more sense tha life."

JOKER'S P.O.V. FINISHING WRITING A NOTE, "On Murray Frank Tonight -- Please Watch!" CLOSE ON STUFFING THE NOTE AND ALL OF RANDALL'S MONEY int envelope-- TURNING ENVELOPE OVER, WRITING "SOPHIE" on the front.

CLOSE ON THE ORANGE CAT AT THE WINDOW, and maybe if we're looking close enough we notice something strange... the c has no reflection. ANGLE OVER JOKER'S SHOULDER OPENING THE WINDOW, shooing t cat out onto the fire escape, out into the dying day--
Go on. Go. You're free.

text: before scampering off out into the world, leaving him beh for good. As he closes the window we almost catch Joker's reflectio the glass--

FOLLOWING BEHIND JOKER, walking down the hallway as if in slow motion, heading for Sophie's apartment. His dyed gre hair now slicked back. He's wearing the ill-fitting rust colored suit he wore to mother's funeral. STILL FROM BEHIND, he lays the envelope in front of Sophi door, then pulls something else out of his pocket -- his obscuring what it is -- puts it down by her door and leav As he walks away down the hallway, we see what else Joker left behind-- HIS WAND OF FLOWERS, at Sophie's door. Hold.

Green hair slicked back like one of the Wall Street assho he killed... White grease paint smeared over his face... nose painted on... dark blue peaks over and under his eye his mother's red lipstick crudely outlining his broken smile... Under the harsh flickering fluorescent lights, h looks like an insane version of his mask. The door closes on his new face. Ding.
Joker steps out of his building into the setting sun, jus Garrity and Burke are getting out of their unmarked Ford Crown Vic--
Hey Arthur, where you going?

Yeah, thought you were coming down                        to the station this morning.                              And Joker takes off running-- Garrity gives chase on foot as Burke hurries back into th car--
Joker darts out from his block into the avenue, sprints across the busy, two-lane street without looking-- Running right in front of an oncoming YELLOW CAB on the f side of the street--

head_text.subj: BAM

text: The cab hits him and Joker goes crashing into the windshi Bounces up and over the car. Landing hard on the pavement The car directly behind the cab skids to a stop just befo running over Joker's face. Swerving into the other lane a CRASHING INTO an oncoming truck. Cars on both sides of the street skidding trying to stop- Crashing. It's chaos.

Joker pops back up from getting hit. He's in pain. But no dead. Garrity has drawn his service revolver as he makes his wa through the pile up. And Burke, now blocked because of th crash has jumped out of his car-- Joker takes off running, limping down the street toward a entrance for the elevated train--
Joker hustling up the stairs, dripping sweat, his white grease-paint running down his face. He gets to the top of stairs, looks back and catches a glimpse of Garrity and B at the bottom--

Joker makes his way down the crowded platform, the passen starting to file on a waiting Lexington Ave/Pelham Expres Train heading downtown. The train's packed with protester heading to the rally at City Hall. Many carrying signs... most of them in "Joker" masks... a few painted up to look like the "Joker" mask. Joker fits in with all of them. He looks through the crowd of clowns and sees the two cop getting to the top of the stairs, looking up and down the platform for him. Pulling out their badges on chains from around their necks. Identifying themselves as cops. Joker's willing the doors to close. But they don't. The two detectives run onto the train just as the doors a finally closing--

Joker moves through the loud train pushing through the ro protesters-- Into the next car, all of them packed. AS THE TRAIN GOES UNDERGROUND, the lights flicker on and car GOING BLACK FOR A FEW SECONDS as the train turns and and speeds down the tracks. Joker glances back at Burke and Garrity pulling out their badges on chains around their necks. Smith & Wesson s revolvers by their sides. Shouting at the crowd, identify themselves as cops.

Joker hears some on the train shouting back in anger at t police, keeps moving... past clown-faced protestors carry signs, "RESIST"... "AM I A CLOWN?"... "SAVE A CITY, KILL YUPPIE"... The two cops push through the car, scanning all the "clow faces... So many look like Joker. They just shove protest out of the way, shouting at them all the while. A few mor voices rising up in protest-- Joker feels Burke and Garrity behind him getting closer. the flickering light sees a DRUNK GUY (20's) wearing a 'Joker' mask and pulls it right off his face-- The drunk guy turns ready to fight. He throws a punch at Joker, and Joker steps out of the wa The guy pummels someone else-- A FIGHT BREAKS OUT, spilling down the car. Joker slips the clown mask over his clown face-- AND JUST STANDS THERE IN THE MIDDLE OF THE CHAOS, at home with the chaos all around him-- Garrity and Burke spot Joker's rust colored suit in the middle of the unruly mob-- Burke pulls his gun-- BURKE
(shouting)

head_text.subj: EVERYBODY DOWN, GOTHAM PD

text: The crowd doesn't drop to the ground. They just keep figh with each other-- Burke sees Joker just standing there. Keeps yelling for t crowd to get down, get down, but they don't listen to him He starts shoving protestors down, out of the way-- and AND THEN THE MOB TURNS ON HIM AND GARRITY, starts closing around them-- Garrity and Burke are pointing their guns at the crowd, yelling panicked for them to back off, back off, and one idiot reaches for Garrity's gun-- Bang.

Burke fires into the crowd, as the train pulls into the station-- A protestor falls dead. The other clowns on the train go crazy, starting to riot. Glimpse Joker walking away calml out of the chaos. Taking off the mask and dropping it at side as he steps off the train, disappearing onto the cro platform.

An excited line of ticket holders waiting to get in to "L with Murray Franklin!" The poster marquee box near the do reads: "TONIGHT'S GUESTS. Lance Reynolds. Dr. Sally Fried And Special Guest." They swing open the doors and start to let the audience inside...
Random fans and autograph hounds hanging out by the backs door, waiting for the night's guests to arrive...

Studio audience filing into the studio, being seated in t wide bleachers along one wall. Three TV monitors hang fro the ceiling, facing the audience. Three studio cameras on floor, black cables strewn everywhere. The set for "LIVE WITH MURRAY FRANKLIN!" is dark... but w can still make out his desk... guest chairs... Don Ellis his Jazz Orchestra's band stand... big blue curtain.

The host of the show, MURRAY FRANKLIN (60's), usually qui with a bemused grin but right now in a sour mood, walks f down the hall toward the drab dressing rooms with his old school producer, GENE UFLAND (60's), who's holding the sh rundown rolled up in his hand.
--You gotta see this nut for yourself, Murray. I don't think we can put him on. With the rioting                         out there.
(annoyed)
Jesus, Gene, I don't have time for this. Cindy's been breaking my balls all day.
She's still mad at you about that thing?
Three marriages, you'd think I'da fuckin' learned something. (then)

What do I gotta see? I already know he's a nut. That's why we're putting him on, it's a goof. A young BLONDE INTERN walks by in the opposite direction. nervously smiles to them and keeps walking. Both men turn check out her ass. Murray winks at Gene.
(just shakes his head, and smiles)
I'm telling you, you gotta see him, Murray. I think it's too risky, the show's too big. It's worth too much to blow it on this,-- this freak.

Joker's sitting on a small couch in the cramped dressing room, watching the local news on a TV that's mounted up o the wall, live shots from the subway station where Burke the protestor, footage of the City Hall rally, clashes wi police. He's cleaned himself up as best he could... white grease- paint smeared more evenly over his face, green dyed hair slicked back in place. Red lips redone. Murray and his producer Gene open the dressing room door without knocking-- Joker gets up off the couch and goes to shake Murray's ha Murray pauses when he sees Joker's face.
(shakes Murray's hand; effusive)
Murray, I can't believe this is real, that I'm really here.
GENE UFLAND
It's Mr. Franklin kid, show some respect. MURRAY FRANKLIN
Oh shut up, Gene. (to Joker) Murray is fine. I prefer it in fact. Thanks for coming on the show. JOKER
Are you kidding? Thank you for the opportunity. I've been watching you forever. My mother never missed a show. Murray nods not listening, he's heard this before. MURRAY FRANKLIN
So what's with the face? Are you part of the protests? JOKER
No, I don't believe in any of that. I don't believe in anything. I just thought it would be good for my act. GENE UFLAND

(upset)                                             Your act? Didn't you hear that a                        kid got killed on the subway and                        two cops who were almost beat to                        death? You didn't hear about the                        dozens of protestors and police                         injured in the riots?                                   Joker looks like he's about to bust out laughing. All of news is playing out on the TV above their heads. He takes deep breath. Swallows the laugh. Beat. JOKER
No. I hadn't heard. Gene and Murray share a look. GENE UFLAND
--the audience is gonna go crazy if you put him on. It was okay maybe for a bit, but not a whole segment.
Murray thinks about it for a beat. MURRAY FRANKLIN

I like it. It's timely. It's edgy. It's, it's dangerous. The best comedy is all those things put together. (done) We're gonna go with it. Gene rubs his temples, he doesn't like this, but Murray i the boss. JOKER
Thank you Murray. MURRAY FRANKLIN

(flashes his bemused smile; condescending) Couple rules though,-- No cussing, no off-color material, we do a clean show, okay? You'll be on after Dr. Sally. Someone will come and get you. Good? Joker nods good. Smiles back at Murray. Murray and Gene turn to go, exchanging smirks with each o as they walk out, making light of Joker who we see behind them still standing there. JOKER
Hey Murray,-- one small thing? When you bring me out, can you introduce me as "The Joker"? Murray and Gene look back at him GENE UFLAND
What? You don't want to use your real name? JOKER
Honestly, I don't even know what my real name is. Joker smiles, the guys can't tell if he's kidding or not. JOKER
Besides, that's what you called me on the show, Murray. A joker. Remember?
(to Gene; trying not to crack up)
Did I?
I have no idea.
(turns back to Joker)
Well, if you say so, kid. Joker it is. Murray starts to laugh at Joker as he closes the dressing room door, shutting it right in his face.

JOKER'S BACKSTAGE AT THE EDGE OF THE BLUE CURTAIN, trying watch the show through a slim gap. Behind him there's a monitor on a cart playing the live feed. He moves the curtain aside to get a better look-- Glimpse Murray laughing, finishing up talking to noted sex therap DR. SALLY FRIEDMAN (60's).
(to Dr. Sally)
You gotta see our next guest for yourself. Will you stick around? Maybe you can help, I'm pretty sure he could use a doctor. The audience laughs.
Oh. Does he have sexual problems?
